articles.headline: Small-Business Loans Will Be Forgiven, but Don’t Ask How
articles.snippet: Owners are flummoxed by how the loan forgiveness phase of the Paycheck Protection Program will work, as lenders await clarity and guidance.
articles.abstract: Owners are flummoxed by how the loan forgiveness phase of the Paycheck Protection Program will work, as lenders await clarity and guidance.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the federal government began the Paycheck Protection Program in April, one rule was clear to small-business owners bedeviled by its chaotic and messy start: If most of the loan money was used to pay employees, the debt would be forgiven.

articles.headline: At Disney World, ‘Worst Fears’ About Virus Have Not Come True
articles.snippet: Attendance has been low since the July reopening, but health officials and worker unions also say safety protocols have kept the coronavirus at bay.
articles.abstract: Attendance has been low since the July reopening, but health officials and worker unions also say safety protocols have kept the coronavirus at bay.
articles.lead_paragraph: In July, one infectious disease expert said Walt Disney World’s reopening was a “terrible idea” that was “inviting disaster.” Social media users attacked Disney as “irresponsible” and “clueless” for pressing forward, even as coronavirus cases surged in Florida. A few aghast onlookers turned Disney World marketing videos into parody trailers for horror films.

articles.headline: Election Less Than a Month Away, Trump Leans on Barr and Pompeo for a Lift
articles.snippet: The secretary of state said he would make Hillary Clinton’s emails public, handing the president a weapon to attack his political foes as the attorney general resisted his overtures to prosecute them.
articles.abstract: The secretary of state said he would make Hillary Clinton’s emails public, handing the president a weapon to attack his political foes as the attorney general resisted his overtures to prosecute them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump forced the State Department on Friday to commit to releasing at least some of Hillary Clinton’s emails before next month’s election, resurrecting a four-year-old issue in hopes that it would prove as helpful to his political prospects as it was when he defeated her in 2016.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Maggie Haberman, Katie Benner, Lara Jakes and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Airline Miles Programs Sure Are Profitable. Are You the Loser?
articles.snippet: United and Delta have been boasting to lenders about fat margins in frequent-flier mile programs. Time for customers to pay a bit more attention.
articles.abstract: United and Delta have been boasting to lenders about fat margins in frequent-flier mile programs. Time for customers to pay a bit more attention.
articles.lead_paragraph: The airlines of the United States have extra-special status. How special? Many of them may get a second pile of coronavirus relief money before citizens who can’t afford to fly get another $1,200 check.

articles.headline: Europe’s Economic Recovery Is a Summer Memory
articles.snippet: As the coronavirus resumes spreading rapidly across the continent, hopes for an economic revival have given way to diminished expectations.
articles.abstract: As the coronavirus resumes spreading rapidly across the continent, hopes for an economic revival have given way to diminished expectations.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — What faint hopes remained that Europe was recovering from the economic catastrophe delivered by the pandemic have disappeared as the lethal virus has resumed spreading rapidly across much of the continent.

articles.headline: Huge Absentee Vote in Key States Favors Democrats So Far
articles.snippet: In Wisconsin, about 146,000 people voted by mail in the 2016 general election. This fall, about 647,000 people have already voted absentee, many in Democratic strongholds.
articles.abstract: In Wisconsin, about 146,000 people voted by mail in the 2016 general election. This fall, about 647,000 people have already voted absentee, many in Democratic strongholds.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Madison, Wis., thousands of people have gone to parks to deliver their ballots during Saturday voting festivals. In Milwaukee, Facebook feeds are inundated with selfies of Democrats inserting ballots into drop boxes. And along the shores of Lake Superior, voters in Wisconsin’s liberal northwest corner still trust the Postal Service to deliver ballots.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein, Nick Corasaniti and Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: The Swamp That Trump Built
articles.snippet: A businessman-president transplanted favor-seeking in Washington to his family’s hotels and resorts — and earned millions as a gatekeeper to his own administration.
articles.abstract: A businessman-president transplanted favor-seeking in Washington to his family’s hotels and resorts — and earned millions as a gatekeeper to his own administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: A businessman-president transplanted favor-seeking in Washington to his family’s hotels and resorts — and earned millions as a gatekeeper to his own administration.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore, Karen Yourish, Steve Eder, Ben Protess, Maggie Haberman, Grace Ashford, Michael LaForgia, Kenneth P. Vogel, Michael Rothfeld and Larry Buchanan

articles.headline: QAnon Is Thriving in Germany. The Extreme Right Is Delighted.
articles.snippet: As the U.S. conspiracy theory goes global, it has found fertile ground in the putsch fantasies and anti-Semitic tropes long popular on Germany’s far-right fringe. Counterterrorism officials worry.
articles.abstract: As the U.S. conspiracy theory goes global, it has found fertile ground in the putsch fantasies and anti-Semitic tropes long popular on Germany’s far-right fringe. Counterterrorism officials worry.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Early in the pandemic, as thousands of American troops began NATO maneuvers in Germany, Attila Hildmann did a quick YouTube search to see what it was all about. He quickly came across videos posted by German followers of QAnon.

articles.headline: In a Small Alabama Town, Suddenly All Politics Is National
articles.snippet: The race for mayor in Montevallo used to be low-key and nonpartisan. In the Trump era, one candidate learned the hard way that’s no longer the case.
articles.abstract: The race for mayor in Montevallo used to be low-key and nonpartisan. In the Trump era, one candidate learned the hard way that’s no longer the case.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTEVALLO, Ala. — Perhaps no one was more surprised to learn that Joyce Jones wanted to defund the police than Joyce Jones herself.

articles.headline: Can Trump Squeeze More From His White Base in Pennsylvania and Beyond?
articles.snippet: With President Trump trailing Joseph R. Biden Jr. in Pennsylvania in nearly every poll, his last refuge and perhaps best hope is to maximize the turnout of working-class white voters.
articles.abstract: With President Trump trailing Joseph R. Biden Jr. in Pennsylvania in nearly every poll, his last refuge and perhaps best hope is to maximize the turnout of working-class white voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: OLYPHANT, Pa. — President Trump’s narrowing path to victory in Pennsylvania, and the country, runs through small towns like Olyphant, where Dave Mitchko’s street might be quieter if not for the large sign he put on his front lawn urging supporters of the president to honk when they pass.

articles.headline: Jaime Harrison Raises $57 Million as Democratic Cash Floods Senate Races
articles.snippet: The amount is the highest quarterly fund-raising total for any Senate candidate in U.S. history and part of an extraordinary surge of money pouring into Democrats’ campaigns.
articles.abstract: The amount is the highest quarterly fund-raising total for any Senate candidate in U.S. history and part of an extraordinary surge of money pouring into Democrats’ campaigns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jaime Harrison, the Democrat challenging Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, raised an astonishing $57 million from July through September, the highest quarterly fund-raising total for any Senate candidate in U.S. history and part of a flood of Democratic money remaking the battle for control of the Senate.
articles.byline: By Maggie Astor, Shane Goldmacher and Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: For Trump, Defying Mideast Truisms Produced Breakthroughs and Backfires
articles.snippet: Disregarding norms and accepted wisdom, President Trump went his own way in the Middle East and, in some cases, got what he wanted.
articles.abstract: Disregarding norms and accepted wisdom, President Trump went his own way in the Middle East and, in some cases, got what he wanted.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — He moved the American Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem, breaking with those who said it would ignite the Muslim world.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger, Ben Hubbard and Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: When Your Last $166 Vanishes: ‘Fast Fraud’ Surges on Payment Apps
articles.snippet: People are getting defrauded as they turn to Square’s Cash App and PayPal’s Venmo to do more online banking in the pandemic.
articles.abstract: People are getting defrauded as they turn to Square’s Cash App and PayPal’s Venmo to do more online banking in the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Charee Mobley, who teaches middle school in Fort Worth, Texas, had just $166 to get herself and her 17-year-old daughter through the last two weeks of August.

articles.headline: Are Amazon Jobs Worth 1,400 Loads of Traffic? French Region Is Split
articles.snippet: The picturesque Gard desperately needs more employment. But environmentalists are pushing back at what they see as a looming blight.
articles.abstract: The picturesque Gard desperately needs more employment. But environmentalists are pushing back at what they see as a looming blight.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOURNÈS, France — On a sultry September morning, Claudie Cortellini headed into the vineyards to survey the grapes that go into her family’s heady Côtes du Rhône wines. In recent years, she has fought to ensure a good harvest as the climate grows warmer. But these days, she is facing an even bigger foe: a giant Amazon sorting center slated for construction near her land.

articles.headline: An Arrest in Canada Casts a Shadow on a New York Times Star, and The Times
articles.snippet: A top editor is now reviewing Rukmini Callimachi’s reporting on terrorism, which turned distant conflicts into accessible stories but drew criticism from colleagues.
articles.abstract: A top editor is now reviewing Rukmini Callimachi’s reporting on terrorism, which turned distant conflicts into accessible stories but drew criticism from colleagues.
articles.lead_paragraph: Derek Henry Flood wasn’t looking for work in March of 2018, when he sent a direct message to a New York Times reporter he admired, Rukmini Callimachi, to congratulate her on the announcement of her big new podcast about the terror group known as the Islamic State.

articles.headline: Rooted in Faith, Amy Coney Barrett Represents a New Conservatism
articles.snippet: As Judge Barrett’s confirmation hearings are set to begin Monday, her background and résumé are a stark departure from those of more traditional nominees to the Supreme Court.
articles.abstract: As Judge Barrett’s confirmation hearings are set to begin Monday, her background and résumé are a stark departure from those of more traditional nominees to the Supreme Court.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a winter afternoon in 2018, Judge Amy Coney Barrett rose to speak in Notre Dame Law School’s wood-paneled courtroom and thanked the people gathered there for joining her for her official investiture as a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Dias, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: The Digital Divide Starts With a Laptop Shortage
articles.snippet: A surge in worldwide demand by educators for low-cost laptops has created shipment delays and pitted desperate schools against one another. Districts with deep pockets often win out.
articles.abstract: A surge in worldwide demand by educators for low-cost laptops has created shipment delays and pitted desperate schools against one another. Districts with deep pockets often win out.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Guilford County Schools in North Carolina spent more than $27 million to buy 66,000 computers and tablets for students over the summer, the district ran into a problem: There was a shortage of cheap laptops, and the devices wouldn’t arrive until late October or November.

articles.headline: British Airways Abruptly Replaces Its Chief Executive
articles.snippet: Alex Cruz, 54, will be replaced by Sean Doyle, who runs Aer Lingus, as the airline industry suffers its “worst crisis.”
articles.abstract: Alex Cruz, 54, will be replaced by Sean Doyle, who runs Aer Lingus, as the airline industry suffers its “worst crisis.”
articles.lead_paragraph: British Airways has said it will cut 13,000 jobs as the coronavirus pandemic batters the airline industry. On Monday, it announced one more job was going: the chief executive’s.

articles.headline: Their Bosses Asked Them to Lead Diversity Reviews. Guess Why.
articles.snippet: When corporations try to belatedly address issues of diversity, equity and inclusion, they often drop the responsibility on their few Black employees.
articles.abstract: When corporations try to belatedly address issues of diversity, equity and inclusion, they often drop the responsibility on their few Black employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last June, Deana Jean received a strange request on LinkedIn: A software company wanted her to lead a diversity, equity and inclusion program for their executive suite.

articles.headline: The Billionaire Who Stood by Jeffrey Epstein
articles.snippet: Leon Black, whose $9 billion fortune could buy the best counsel in the world, paid at least $50 million to Mr. Epstein for advice and services after most others had deserted him.
articles.abstract: Leon Black, whose $9 billion fortune could buy the best counsel in the world, paid at least $50 million to Mr. Epstein for advice and services after most others had deserted him.
articles.lead_paragraph: The billionaire financier Leon Black, one of Wall Street’s most powerful executives, was facing questions from clients after Jeffrey Epstein was arrested last year on federal sex trafficking charges. The two men had known each other for decades, and investors of Mr. Black’s investment company, Apollo Global Management, wanted to know how close they had been.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, Steve Eder and David Enrich

articles.headline: No Home, No Wi-Fi: Pandemic Adds to Strain on Poor College Students
articles.snippet: Some low-income students have dropped out, and there are growing concerns about hunger and homelessness.
articles.abstract: Some low-income students have dropped out, and there are growing concerns about hunger and homelessness.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michelle Macario was struggling to follow online classes through the tiny screen of her smartphone. She had no laptop and no Wi-Fi at home, and the library where she normally studied at her community college in Los Angeles was closed. So two weeks into the coronavirus shutdown in the spring, she dropped all of her courses to avoid failing.

articles.headline: U.S. Auction Theorists Win the 2020 Nobel in Economics
articles.snippet: Paul Milgrom and Robert Wilson were honored for work that has pushed auctions into new and useful territory.
articles.abstract: Paul Milgrom and Robert Wilson were honored for work that has pushed auctions into new and useful territory.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two American economists, Paul R. Milgrom and Robert B. Wilson, were awarded the Nobel in economic science on Monday for improvements to auction theory and inventions of new auction formats — innovations that have had huge practical applications when it comes to allocating scarce resources.

articles.headline: ‘We Were Bulletproof’: As Child Soldiers Grow Up, Legacy of War Lingers
articles.snippet: Twin leaders of Myanmar’s God’s Army were once thought to have magical powers. Now adults, they are contending with the trauma of exile, alcohol and loss.
articles.abstract: Twin leaders of Myanmar’s God’s Army were once thought to have magical powers. Now adults, they are contending with the trauma of exile, alcohol and loss.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAT THAN KWIN, Myanmar — Johnny Htoo lay on a concrete floor. His eyes stared at nothing in particular.
